conversation.content: So I've been thinking about everything we talked about last week, and honestly, I think I need to take a step back from all of this for a while, you know?

That's completely understandable, really it is. Sometimes the best thing you can do is give yourself space to process everything without pressure. What brought you to this decision, if you don't mind me asking?
[chuckle] It's funny, actually, because it was something my therapist said about patterns and how we keep repeating them expecting different results.

[friendly] Your therapist sounds pretty insightful there. Breaking patterns is one of the hardest things humans do because our brains literally create neural highways that make the familiar path feel like the only path. It takes real courage to step off that highway and forge something new.
[long pause] Yeah, well, I guess this is me being courageous then, even though it feels more like running away if I'm being honest with myself.

Running away and taking strategic distance are two completely different things though. One is fear-based avoidance, the other is intentional self-care with a purpose. From where I'm sitting, this sounds much more like the second one.
You always know exactly what to say to make me feel less crazy about my decisions, but I'm still not sure if I'm doing the right thing here.

[mumbling] Nobody ever really knows if they're doing the right thing in the moment, that's the thing about life decisions. The "right thing" only becomes clear in retrospect, usually months or years later when you can see how all the pieces fit together.
That's both comforting and terrifying at the same time, thanks for that perspective.

Life's full of those paradoxes, isn't it? The things that comfort us also scare us, the things we want most require giving up what we have. It's all about finding peace with the uncertainty rather than waiting for guarantees that never come.
Speaking of uncertainty, I should probably mention that I already started packing my things from the office this morning.
Oh wow, so you're really moving forward with this quickly then. That must have been emotional, clearing out your space after three years. How did it feel being there knowing it was the last time?
Honestly? It felt like a weight lifting that I didn't even know I was carrying around all this time.

[confused] Wait, I thought you loved that job though? You were always talking about the team and the projects and how fulfilling the work was. Did something specific happen that changed your perspective so dramatically?
[jealous] Yeah well, watching Davidson get promoted to the position I'd been promised for two years straight kind of opened my eyes to reality.

That's a brutal wake-up call, and I'm sorry you had to experience that betrayal. When organizations show you through actions that your contributions aren't valued the way they claim, believing them becomes impossible. You deserve to be somewhere that recognizes your worth.
Exactly, and that's why I'm done playing their games and jumping through hoops that lead nowhere.

Good for you, seriously, that takes guts. Most people stay in situations like that for years, decades even, hoping things will magically change. The fact that you're choosing yourself and your wellbeing over the false security is incredibly mature.
[loudly] You know what? You're absolutely right! I should be celebrating this decision instead of second-guessing myself every five minutes!

[loudly] Yes! That's the energy you need right now! This is the beginning of something better, not the end of something good, and once you really embrace that mindset, everything else will start falling into place!
